home.second_headline: We asked AI - How is Dortmund 2025 changing through politics...

details.title: More Information
details.text: We analyzed the data about the party's program using AI to identify visual changes. This resulted in the following thought process (reasoning):
details.closing1: The results of this analysis were then visualized using an image-generating model. Further details on the party's political content can be found in the corresponding
details.closing2: . Further information on the technical implementation can be found on the ‘About the project’ page.

priv.name: Privacy Policy
priv.content:
Our website is hosted via GitHub Pages (GitHub, Inc., 88 Colin P. Kelly Jr. Street, San Francisco, CA 94107, USA).
When you visit our pages, GitHub automatically collects log data (e.g., IP address, browser type, time of access) to ensure the security and functionality of the service.
We do not have access to or process this data ourselves.

Our website also contains links to external third-party websites (e.g., YouTube, LinkedIn). When you click on these links, you leave our website. The operators of those linked sites are solely responsible for their content and the processing of personal data.

Beyond this, we do not use cookies, tracking, or analytics tools, and no further personal data is processed.

about.text_top:
The local elections in North Rhine-Westphalia are coming up, and as a group of young AI enthusiasts, we ask ourselves: can this innovative technology also be used to positively influence political education and local voter turnout? For example, by using AI to make party politics more understandable and accessible?

In Dortmund, we are therefore experimentally applying generative AI in the context of local elections to promote the Young AI Leaders Community to advance Sustainable Development Goal 4: Quality Education. The promotion of local political education is to be achieved through local and transparent technical implementation.

Our project was shaped by intensive exchanges with the Lamarr Institute (an AI research center), the Jugendring Dortmund (which collaborates on the Kommunalomat) and Max Mundhenke (developer of bundestagswahl.ai) – thank you very much for your input!
about.text_tech1: We use the election programs and responses to the Kommunalomat survey as our data source. This content was provided to us either directly by the parties or by the Dortmund Youth Council. The data was processed independently using a generative language model (the AI) to determine how the municipality could be visually transformed by the program. This potential transformation is visualized in the final step using an image-generating AI model.
about.text_tech2: Due to the considerable risks associated with the use of generative AI, it is our personal goal to implement this project as transparently as possible. We use the Qwen3-30B-A3B for analysis (including reasoning) and FLUX.1 [schnell] for image generation. In addition, BART was used for summarizing and TowerInstruct-13B-v0.1 for translating the content. Further technical details can be found in our GitHub repository.
about.text_team1: As part of the global AI for Good Initiative, the Young AI Leaders Dortmund are investigating how young people can drive positive change with the help of AI. This hub project was realized by the following members of our hub (click for more information):
about.text_team2:
Would you like to learn more or exchange ideas with us? Then feel free to connect with us or contact us by email:

dortmundhub.youngaileaders [at] gmail.com

disclaimer.title: Disclaimer
disclaimer.text: The content presented is experimental and does not serve as a voting recommendation. It was created using generative AI and is intended solely to stimulate discourse and political education. Due to the processing with AI, the positions of the parties may be inaccurately or incorrectly represented. Please inform yourself thoroughly before the election. Further information can be found, for example, on the website of the city of Dortmund.
